data.title: Port of Londonderry Emigrant Lists [ Emigrants ] : Free Genealogy Pages from Ulster Ancestry
data.text:
Passenger book - Londonderry to Philadelphia, New Orleans, Quebec and St. John [277 pages]. See end of list for transcript.

Total 202 souls making 166 adults (ÃÂ¼ on Messrs. Craig's order)

Net sum received ÃÂ£493 1s.

Cancellations

James and Eliza Gallagher and children Sarah 3 and William 1 year; also William Coll. An earnest of 10s. was paid on 20th February 1847 and a further 30s. was to be given on the following Wednesday against the total passage money of ÃÂ£16.

Joseph Duncan of Plumbridge, Co. Tyrone. An earnest of 7s. was paid on 25th February 1847 against passage money of ÃÂ£4 4s.

Hugh and Peggy Crilly, Draperstown, Co. Londonderry and child Mary 9 months. An earnest of 5s. against passage money of ÃÂ£10 5s. was paid to Bess Getty a local agent on 26th February 1847.

Susan and Michael Mullen, Beragh, Co. Tyrone. An earnest of 10s. against passage money of ÃÂ£8 10s. was paid on 2nd March.

John Harly (?) of Fannett, Co. Donegal. An earnest of 10s. was paid against passage money of ÃÂ£4 5s.

Nola (?) Conway, Newtownstewart and child John 11 years.

Daniel and Ellenor McConlogue, Carndonagh, Co. Donegal and children Mary 12, James 10, Catherine 8, David 6, Ellen 4, Susanna 3 months. An earnest of ÃÂ£1 against passage money of ÃÂ£26 15s. was paid on 3 March. ÃÂ£3 more was to be paid 'this day week or bargain void'.

Patrick Coyle, Milford, Co. Donegal. An earnest of 5s. against passage money of ÃÂ£4 4s. was paid to the local agent S. Hay on 4th March 1847.

Francis Kelly, Fintona, Co. Tyrone. An earnest of ÃÂ£1 was paid to J. Campbell on 4th March against passage money of ÃÂ£4 4s.

Sarah Jane McGrillan, Coleraine, Co. Londonderry. An earnest of ÃÂ£1 was paid to J. Clark against passage money of ÃÂ£4 4s.

Distribution of the 202 passengers (address is not always given)

82 from Co. Donegal

75 from Co. Londonderry

40 from Co. Tyrone and 3 from Co. Antrim

63 of the passages were paid for in Londonderry, 60 through local agents in the provincial towns and 78 on the order of Andrew C. Craig and Co., apparently American agents.
